speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: SCENE XIII. Alexandria. CLEOPATRA's palace.

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: Enter CLEOPATRA, DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS, CHARMIAN, and IRAS

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: What shall we do, Enobarbus?

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Think, and die.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Is Antony or we in fault for this?

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Antony only, that would make his will

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Lord of his reason. What though you fled

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: From that great face of war, whose several ranges

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Frighted each other? why should he follow?

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: The itch of his affection should not then

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Have nick'd his captainship; at such a point,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: When half to half the world opposed, he being

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: The meered question: 'twas a shame no less

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Than was his loss, to course your flying flags,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: And leave his navy gazing.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Prithee, peace.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Enter MARK ANTONY with EUPHRONIUS, the Ambassador

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Is that his answer?

speaker: EUPHRONIUS
text_entry: Ay, my lord.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The queen shall then have courtesy, so she

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Will yield us up.

speaker: EUPHRONIUS
text_entry: He says so.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Let her know't.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To the boy Caesar send this grizzled head,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And he will fill thy wishes to the brim

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: With principalities.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: That head, my lord?

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To him again: tell him he wears the rose

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Of youth upon him; from which the world should note

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Something particular: his coin, ships, legions,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: May be a coward's; whose ministers would prevail

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Under the service of a child as soon

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: As i' the command of Caesar: I dare him therefore

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To lay his gay comparisons apart,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And answer me declined, sword against sword,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Ourselves alone. I'll write it: follow me.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Exeunt MARK ANTONY and EUPHRONIUS

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: [Aside]  Yes, like enough, high-battled Caesar will

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Unstate his happiness, and be staged to the show,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Against a sworder! I see men's judgments are

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: A parcel of their fortunes; and things outward

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Do draw the inward quality after them,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: To suffer all alike. That he should dream,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Knowing all measures, the full Caesar will

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Answer his emptiness! Caesar, thou hast subdued

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: His judgment too.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Enter an Attendant

speaker: Attendant
text_entry: A messenger from CAESAR.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: What, no more ceremony? See, my women!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Against the blown rose may they stop their nose

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: That kneel'd unto the buds. Admit him, sir.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Exit Attendant

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: [Aside]  Mine honesty and I begin to square.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: The loyalty well held to fools does make

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Our faith mere folly: yet he that can endure

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: To follow with allegiance a fall'n lord

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Does conquer him that did his master conquer

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: And earns a place i' the story.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Enter THYREUS

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Caesar's will?

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: Hear it apart.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: None but friends: say boldly.

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: So, haply, are they friends to Antony.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: He needs as many, sir, as Caesar has;

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Or needs not us. If Caesar please, our master

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Will leap to be his friend: for us, you know,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Whose he is we are, and that is, Caesar's.

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: So.

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: Thus then, thou most renown'd: Caesar entreats,

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: Not to consider in what case thou stand'st,

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: Further than he is Caesar.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Go on: right royal.

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: He knows that you embrace not Antony

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: As you did love, but as you fear'd him.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: O!

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: The scars upon your honour, therefore, he

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: Does pity, as constrained blemishes,

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: Not as deserved.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: He is a god, and knows

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: What is most right: mine honour was not yielded,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: But conquer'd merely.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: [Aside]             To be sure of that,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: I will ask Antony. Sir, sir, thou art so leaky,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: That we must leave thee to thy sinking, for

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Thy dearest quit thee.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: Shall I say to Caesar

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: What you require of him? for he partly begs

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: To be desired to give. It much would please him,

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: That of his fortunes you should make a staff

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: To lean upon: but it would warm his spirits,

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: To hear from me you had left Antony,

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: And put yourself under his shrowd,

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: The universal landlord.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: What's your name?

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: My name is Thyreus.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Most kind messenger,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Say to great Caesar this: in deputation

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I kiss his conquering hand: tell him, I am prompt

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: To lay my crown at 's feet, and there to kneel:

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Tell him from his all-obeying breath I hear

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: The doom of Egypt.

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: 'Tis your noblest course.

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: Wisdom and fortune combating together,

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: If that the former dare but what it can,

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: No chance may shake it. Give me grace to lay

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: My duty on your hand.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Your Caesar's father oft,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: When he hath mused of taking kingdoms in,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Bestow'd his lips on that unworthy place,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: As it rain'd kisses.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Re-enter MARK ANTONY and DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Favours, by Jove that thunders!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: What art thou, fellow?

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: One that but performs

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: The bidding of the fullest man, and worthiest

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: To have command obey'd.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: [Aside]               You will be whipp'd.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Approach, there! Ah, you kite! Now, gods

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: and devils!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Authority melts from me: of late, when I cried 'Ho!'

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Like boys unto a muss, kings would start forth,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And cry 'Your will?' Have you no ears? I am

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Antony yet.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Enter Attendants

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Take hence this Jack, and whip him.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: [Aside]  'Tis better playing with a lion's whelp

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Than with an old one dying.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Moon and stars!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Whip him. Were't twenty of the greatest tributaries

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: That do acknowledge Caesar, should I find them

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: So saucy with the hand of she here,--what's her name,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Since she was Cleopatra? Whip him, fellows,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Till, like a boy, you see him cringe his face,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And whine aloud for mercy: take him hence.

speaker: THYREUS
text_entry: Mark Antony!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Tug him away: being whipp'd,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Bring him again: this Jack of Caesar's shall

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Bear us an errand to him.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Exeunt Attendants with THYREUS

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: You were half blasted ere I knew you: ha!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Have I my pillow left unpress'd in Rome,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Forborne the getting of a lawful race,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And by a gem of women, to be abused

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: By one that looks on feeders?

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Good my lord,--

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: You have been a boggler ever:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: But when we in our viciousness grow hard--

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: O misery on't!--the wise gods seel our eyes;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: In our own filth drop our clear judgments; make us

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Adore our errors; laugh at's, while we strut

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To our confusion.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: O, is't come to this?

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I found you as a morsel cold upon

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Dead Caesar's trencher; nay, you were a fragment

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Of Cneius Pompey's; besides what hotter hours,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Unregister'd in vulgar fame, you have

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Luxuriously pick'd out: for, I am sure,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Though you can guess what temperance should be,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: You know not what it is.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Wherefore is this?

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To let a fellow that will take rewards

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And say 'God quit you!' be familiar with

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: My playfellow, your hand; this kingly seal

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And plighter of high hearts! O, that I were

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Upon the hill of Basan, to outroar

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The horned herd! for I have savage cause;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And to proclaim it civilly, were like

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: A halter'd neck which does the hangman thank

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: For being yare about him.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Re-enter Attendants with THYREUS

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Is he whipp'd?

speaker: First Attendant
text_entry: Soundly, my lord.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Cried he? and begg'd a' pardon?

speaker: First Attendant
text_entry: He did ask favour.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: If that thy father live, let him repent

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Thou wast not made his daughter; and be thou sorry

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To follow Caesar in his triumph, since

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Thou hast been whipp'd for following him: henceforth

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The white hand of a lady fever thee,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Shake thou to look on 't. Get thee back to Caesar,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Tell him thy entertainment: look, thou say

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: He makes me angry with him; for he seems

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Proud and disdainful, harping on what I am,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Not what he knew I was: he makes me angry;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And at this time most easy 'tis to do't,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: When my good stars, that were my former guides,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Have empty left their orbs, and shot their fires

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Into the abysm of hell. If he mislike

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: My speech and what is done, tell him he has

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Hipparchus, my enfranched bondman, whom

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: He may at pleasure whip, or hang, or torture,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: As he shall like, to quit me: urge it thou:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Hence with thy stripes, begone!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Exit THYREUS

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Have you done yet?

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Alack, our terrene moon

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Is now eclipsed; and it portends alone

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The fall of Antony!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I must stay his time.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To flatter Caesar, would you mingle eyes

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: With one that ties his points?

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Not know me yet?

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Cold-hearted toward me?

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Ah, dear, if I be so,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: From my cold heart let heaven engender hail,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: And poison it in the source; and the first stone

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Drop in my neck: as it determines, so

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Dissolve my life! The next Caesarion smite!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Till by degrees the memory of my womb,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Together with my brave Egyptians all,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: By the discandying of this pelleted storm,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Lie graveless, till the flies and gnats of Nile

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Have buried them for prey!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I am satisfied.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Caesar sits down in Alexandria; where

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I will oppose his fate. Our force by land

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Hath nobly held; our sever'd navy too

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Have knit again, and fleet, threatening most sea-like.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Where hast thou been, my heart? Dost thou hear, lady?

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: If from the field I shall return once more

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: To kiss these lips, I will appear in blood;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I and my sword will earn our chronicle:

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: There's hope in't yet.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: That's my brave lord!

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I will be treble-sinew'd, hearted, breathed,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And fight maliciously: for when mine hours

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Were nice and lucky, men did ransom lives

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Of me for jests; but now I'll set my teeth,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: And send to darkness all that stop me. Come,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Let's have one other gaudy night: call to me

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: All my sad captains; fill our bowls once more;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Let's mock the midnight bell.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: It is my birth-day:

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I had thought to have held it poor: but, since my lord

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Is Antony again, I will be Cleopatra.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: We will yet do well.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Call all his noble captains to my lord.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Do so, we'll speak to them; and to-night I'll force

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: The wine peep through their scars. Come on, my queen;

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: There's sap in't yet. The next time I do fight,

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: I'll make death love me; for I will contend

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Even with his pestilent scythe.

speaker: MARK ANTONY
text_entry: Exeunt all but DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Now he'll outstare the lightning. To be furious,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Is to be frighted out of fear; and in that mood

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: The dove will peck the estridge; and I see still,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: A diminution in our captain's brain

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Restores his heart: when valour preys on reason,

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: It eats the sword it fights with. I will seek

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Some way to leave him.

speaker: DOMITIUS ENOBARBUS
text_entry: Exit
